description_narrative: Within the proposed project Schiphorst Holding and Gardi Tours will establish a private training institute in hotel and tourism management. The Institute will offer a one year college programme for students and contracted training for shorter periods for employees in the hotel and tourism industry. The Institute will consist of classroom training facilities, as well as on-the-job training facilities in the form of limited hotel rooms, a restaurant and hotel reception and shop. Next to the Institute a dormitory will be constructed for on-campus students from outside Ulaanbaatar.The training programme will be developed, implemented and monitored by INHolland University of Applied Sciences, Department of Tourism and Recreation management, and the Mongolian University of Science and Technology (MUST), Department of Tourism management and Regional studies. INHolland and MUST will train the Mongolian teachers who will teach students and hotel/tourism personnel at the Institute.The rationale for the proposed project is the rapid growth of the tourism industry in Mongolia combined with the current lack of adequately trained Mongolian hotel and tourism management personnel. At the Institute Mongolian students and hotel/tourism personnel will acquire the necessary professional skills in order to acquire management positions in one of the existing or new (international) hotels and tourism enterprises in Mongolia. The majority of management jobs are currently occupied by foreign personnel due to the lack of qualified Mongolians. Through the 'upgrading' of professional skills in hotel and tourism management, this project will improve the employment opportunities and income conditions for Mongolian students and people working in the hotel and tourism industry and provide a stimulus for the further development of the industry in Mongolia.Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)The project is supported by the Mongolian Ministries of Education and Tourism. The Institute and the educational programme will be certified by the Ministry of Education.Impact•	Employment and working conditionsThe Institute will employ 8 full-time Mongolian mentor and assistant teachers, 4 part-time Mongolian/foreign visiting lecturers and 8 Mongolian / foreign staff members. Besides 3 Mongolian guards, all are medium-/high-level employees. In the second year after the project's completion the Institute will employ 14 full-time Mongolian teachers, 7 part-time Mongolian/foreign visiting lecturers and 11 Mongolian/foreign staff members, of which 3 guards. Wages are on average 20% higher than the regular wages for similar jobs in Mongolia. This is related to the higher workload of mentor and assistant teachers compared to regular schools and universities. All teachers will be given board and lodging in the city or at the campus and a contribution in their pension and medical insurance plan.•	Innovation / Transfer of knowledgeThe envisioned concept of vocational training in a realistic hotel/restaurant setting, similar to the European "hotel schools", is completely new in Mongolia. The transfer of knowledge will focus on understanding western expectations of the touristic product. This aspect is new to Mongolian teachers in the field of hotel/tourism management. After being trained by staff from INHolland and MUST, they will in turn transfer this knowledge to Mongolian students and hotel / tourism personnel. The knowledge transfer will lead to an 'upgrading' of professional skills in hotel and tourism management in Mongolia.•	Chain effectsThrough the 'upgrading' of professional skills in hotel and tourism management, the project will improve the employment opportunities for Mongolian students and people working in the hotel and tourism industry. The availability of qualified local hotel/tourism personnel will in turn stimulate further development of the tourism industry in Mongolia.It is expected that other public and private universities in Mongolia will copy the vocational training methods. In fact, the Mongolian Ministry of Education has already adopted a policy of stimulating vocational training centres.•	EnvironmentThe construction of the Institute will pose no environmental threat since there is no special flora or fauna at the site in Ulaanbaatar. The Institute will pay special attention to responsible management regarding the environment. Hotel/tourism managers who are trained at the Institute will influence the decision making process regarding environmental aspects in their own companies.•	Position of womenWithin the workforce of teachers and staff, special attention will be paid with respect to hiring female employees. They will have equal salary and rights for similar positions as male employees.

The foundation of a private training institute in hotel and tourism management offering a one year college programme for students and contracted training for employees in the hotel and tourism industry in Mongolia.

title_narrative: Strengthening capacity of coalitions
sector_narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
reporting_org_narrative: Oxfam Novib
participating_org_narrative: Fisheries Action Coalition Team (FACT) is a coalition of NGOs established in 2000 by a group of NGO members working on fisheries and environmental issues around the Tonle Sap Lake. It was established as part of the environment project of the NGO Forum onCambodia.At that time, a group of NGOs interested in fisheries issues formed a sub-working group which then was supported by different international NGOs such as Oxfam, NGO Forum on Cambodia, and Environment Justice-Foundation. The group of eight NGOs later decided to form the Fisheries Action Coalition Team. In January 2004, FACT separated forum the NGO Forum on Cambodia following the reform in fisheries sector of Cambodia, in which the government declared to release up to 56% of the commercial fishinglots to community management. FACT#s active members are all Cambodian NGO staff members who are committed to conducting advocacy in fisheries issues and monitoring policy reforms. FACT#s program mobilizes provincial NGOs and Community Based Organizations(CBOs) to more effective conduct advocacy programs that respond to development policies and development programs. FACT focuses its work around the Tonle Sap, Coastal and Mekong provinces, on issues that affect Cambodian communities# livelihoods. FACT collaborates with NGOs concerned with fisheries involved with local fishing communities. FACT works towards building a strong coalition of NGOs and local grassroots# organizations to protect fisheries, water resources and other natural resources in Tonle SapLake, Mekong River, and Cambodian marine regions along the coastal provinces.

description_narrative: Fisheries Action Coalition Team (FACT) is a coalition of NGOs established in 2000 by a group of NGO members working on fisheries and environmental issues around the Tonle Sap Lake. It was established as part of the environment project of the NGO Forum onCambodia.At that time, a group of NGOs interested in fisheries issues formed a sub-working group which then was supported by different international NGOs such as Oxfam, NGO Forum on Cambodia, and Environment Justice-Foundation. The group of eight NGOs later decided to form the Fisheries Action Coalition Team. In January 2004, FACT separated from the NGO Forum on Cambodia following the reform in fisheries sector of Cambodia, in which the government declared to release up to 56% of the commercial fishing lots to community management. FACT#s active members are all Cambodian NGO staff members who are committed to conducting advocacy in fisheries issues and monitoring policy reforms. FACT#s program mobilizes provincial NGOs and Community Based Organizations (CBOs) to more effective conduct advocacy programs that respond to development policies and development programs. FACT focuses its work around the Tonle Sap, Coastal andMekong provinces, on issues that affect Cambodian communities# livelihoods. FACT collaborates with NGOs concerned with fisheries involved with local fishing communities. FACT works towards building a strong coalition of NGOs and local grassroots# organizations toprotect fisheries, water resources and other natural resources in Tonle Sap Lake, Mekong River, and Cambodian marine regions along the coastal provinces.Under this requested project FACT aim contribute to the improvement of policies and law enforcement, better access to and control of fishery resources, and improved livelihoods.To achieve about aim, the followings are the project outcomesand project activities which FACT proposed to work within the 12 months period, Jan - Dec 2020.Outcome 1: CCF and NGO-CF are strengthened to become better organized and more professionalOutput 1: Providing capacity to CCBO and NGO partners on natural/fisheries resources management, and other legal frameworks such as Environment Law, Fisheries Law, Sub-Decrees related to fisheries resources managementActivity 1.2.1 (budget code2.1) Training courses on relevant subjects to NGO-CF: FACT will conduct one training to NGOCoalition on Fisheries (NGO-CF) members with expectation of 30 participants, of whom at least 10 is women. Topic of training is related to one or more of these subjects: Advocacy skill, communication skills, leadership and related fisheries legal framework,#etc. The specific subjects will be identified during the first meeting of NGO-CF.Activity 1.2.2 (budget code 2.2) Training courses on relevant subjects toCCF: FACT will conduct one training to Coalition of Cambodia Fishers (CCF) members with expectation of 55 participants, of whom at least 20 is women. Topic of training is related to one or more of these subjects: Advocacy skill, communication skills, leadership and related fisheries legal framework,#etc. The specific subjects will be identified during the first meeting of CCF.Activity 1.2.3 (budget code 2.3) Conduct study tour/annual reflection for NGO-CF members: FACT will conduct a study tour/reflection by inviting around 30 NGO-CF members, of whom at least 10 is women. The purpose of this study tour is to reflect the annual achievements of NGO-CF#s work and plan for next year and exchange more experiences, lesson learnt and challenges in networkingand advocacy on fisheries resources management among the partners and other outside partners.Activity 1.2..4 (budget code 2.4) Conduct study tour/annual reflection for CCF members: FACT will conduct a study tour/annual reflection by inviting around 30NGO-CF members, of whom at least 10 is women. The purpose of this study tour is to reflect the annual achievements of NGO-CF#s work and plan for next year and exchange more experiences, lesson learnt and challenges in networking and advocacy on fisheriesresources management among thepartners and other outside partners.Outcome 2:  NGOs partners and fishers representatives are empowered and partner with Fisheries Administration to advocate for better fisheries resources management via policy dialogues and advocacy campaignsOutput 2.1 Policy dialogues on and advocacy activities at sub-national and national levels, for better fisheries resources management have been conducted.Activity 2.1.1 (budget code 2.5). Conduct NGO-CF meeting (3 times/year): FACT will keep strengthening the existing nationalNGO network NGO Coalition on Fisheries (NGO-CF) with 46 NGO partners. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss internally among theNGO partners of the network on internal issue # including workingstrategy to partner with FiA and other government officials # monitor the progresses of the results of the both previous internal NGO partners and main Cambodia Fisheries Network (CFN) meeting whereFiA also joined and prepare for the coming main CFN meeting.Activity 2.1.2 (budget code 2.6). Conduct CCF meeting (3times/year): FACT will keep supporting CCF to host its CCF meetings (3times/year) in which around 55 CBO/CFi members are invited to join. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss internallyamongthe 55 CFi-members of the CCF on internal issue # including working strategy to work with NGO partners and partner with FiA and other government officials # monitor the progresses of the results of the previous internal CCF and main CFN meeting wherebothNGO partners and FiA also joined and prepare for the coming main CFN meeting.Activity 2.1.3(budget code 2.7). Conduct main CFN meeting (2times/year): FACT will keep organizing meeting of Cambodia Fisheries Network (CFN) where representatives ofNGO-CF members, CCF members , and around 17 national FiA and FiA cantonment officials are members and invited to join. It#s expected that around 60participants,  of whom at least 25 is women, will be invited to join each of the meeting The purpose ofthe meeting is to review the progresses of the relevant issues/challenges raised in previous meeting(s) and discuss on new fisheries related issues, including illegal fishing activities, policies,#etc.Activity 2.1.4 (budget code 2.8) Conduct sub-nationalCFN meeting: FACT will coordinate to organize sub-  sub-national CFN meeting among NGO partners, CCF, and/or competent authorities (provincial FiA, authorities, policy, courts,#) to address the fisheries related issues at regional levels (Mekong, Tonle Sap, andcoastal). At least two meetings and 40 participants, of whom at least 10 is women, at each of the region will be organized. The main purpose of the meeting is address any fisheries related issues in which can be addressed at sub-national levelwithout bringing the issues to national level. There be at least 150 participants will be invited to join each forum.Activity 2.1.4 Conduct national round table/forum discussion: FACT will conduct one national public forum. The purpose of the forum is toshare fisheries related issues and together address the identified issues, in which can#t by addressed by and selected by CFN or NGO partners, among other multi-stakeholders such as FiA, MoE, MAFF, MoI, and court. The forum also aims at discussing onother legalframeworks such as amendment of Fisheries Law, Sub-degree on CFi management. There will be at least 60 participants will be invited to join this forum, of whom at least 25 is women.

description_narrative: Fisheries Action Coalition Team (FACT) is a coalition of NGOs established in 2000 by a group of NGO members working on fisheries and environmental issues around the Tonle Sap Lake. It was established as part of the environment project of the NGO Forum onCambodia.At that time, a group of NGOs interested in fisheries issues formed a sub-working group which then was supported by different international NGOs such as Oxfam, NGO Forum on Cambodia, and Environment Justice-Foundation. The group of eight NGOs later decided to form the Fisheries Action Coalition Team. In January 2004, FACT separated from the NGO Forum on Cambodia following the reform in fisheries sector of Cambodia, in which the government declared to release up to 56% of the commercial fishing lots to community management. FACT#s active members are all Cambodian NGO staff members who are committed to conducting advocacy in fisheries issues and monitoring policy reforms. FACT#s program mobilizes provincial NGOs and Community Based Organizations (CBOs) to more effective conduct advocacy programs that respond to development policies and development programs. FACT focuses its work around the Tonle Sap, Coastal andMekong provinces, on issues that affect Cambodian communities# livelihoods. FACT collaborates with NGOs concerned with fisheries involved with local fishing communities. FACT works towards building a strong coalition of NGOs and local grassroots# organizations toprotect fisheries, water resources and other natural resources in Tonle Sap Lake, Mekong River, and Cambodian marine regions along the coastal provinces.Under this requested project FACT aim contribute to the improvement of policies and law enforcement, better access to and control of fishery resources, and improved livelihoods.To achieve about aim, the followings are the project outcomesand project activities which FACT proposed to work within the 12 months period, Jan - Dec 2020.Outcome 1: CCF and NGO-CF are strengthened to become better organized and more professionalOutput 1: Providing capacity to CCBO and NGO partners on natural/fisheries resources management, and other legal frameworks such as Environment Law, Fisheries Law, Sub-Decrees related to fisheries resources managementActivity 1.2.1 (budget code2.1) Training courses on relevant subjects to NGO-CF: FACT will conduct one training to NGOCoalition on Fisheries (NGO-CF) members with expectation of 30 participants, of whom at least 10 is women. Topic of training is related to one or more of these subjects: Advocacy skill, communication skills, leadership and related fisheries legal framework,#etc. The specific subjects will be identified during the first meeting of NGO-CF.Activity 1.2.2 (budget code 2.2) Training courses on relevant subjects toCCF: FACT will conduct one training to Coalition of Cambodia Fishers (CCF) members with expectation of 55 participants, of whom at least 20 is women. Topic of training is related to one or more of these subjects: Advocacy skill, communication skills, leadership and related fisheries legal framework,#etc. The specific subjects will be identified during the first meeting of CCF.Activity 1.2.3 (budget code 2.3) Conduct study tour/annual reflection for NGO-CF members: FACT will conduct a study tour/reflection by inviting around 30 NGO-CF members, of whom at least 10 is women. The purpose of this study tour is to reflect the annual achievements of NGO-CF#s work and plan for next year and exchange more experiences, lesson learnt and challenges in networkingand advocacy on fisheries resources management among the partners and other outside partners.Activity 1.2..4 (budget code 2.4) Conduct study tour/annual reflection for CCF members: FACT will conduct a study tour/annual reflection by inviting around 30NGO-CF members, of whom at least 10 is women. The purpose of this study tour is to reflect the annual achievements of NGO-CF#s work and plan for next year and exchange more experiences, lesson learnt and challenges in networking and advocacy on fisheriesresources management among thepartners and other outside partners.Outcome 2:  NGOs partners and fishers representatives are empowered and partner with Fisheries Administration to advocate for better fisheries resources management via policy dialogues and advocacy campaignsOutput 2.1 Policy dialogues on and advocacy activities at sub-national and national levels, for better fisheries resources management have been conducted.Activity 2.1.1 (budget code 2.5). Conduct NGO-CF meeting (3 times/year): FACT will keep strengthening the existing nationalNGO network NGO Coalition on Fisheries (NGO-CF) with 46 NGO partners. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss internally among theNGO partners of the network on internal issue # including workingstrategy to partner with FiA and other government officials # monitor the progresses of the results of the both previous internal NGO partners and main Cambodia Fisheries Network (CFN) meeting whereFiA also joined and prepare for the coming main CFN meeting.Activity 2.1.2 (budget code 2.6). Conduct CCF meeting (3times/year): FACT will keep supporting CCF to host its CCF meetings (3times/year) in which around 55 CBO/CFi members are invited to join. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss internallyamongthe 55 CFi-members of the CCF on internal issue # including working strategy to work with NGO partners and partner with FiA and other government officials # monitor the progresses of the results of the previous internal CCF and main CFN meeting wherebothNGO partners and FiA also joined and prepare for the coming main CFN meeting.Activity 2.1.3(budget code 2.7). Conduct main CFN meeting (2times/year): FACT will keep organizing meeting of Cambodia Fisheries Network (CFN) where representatives ofNGO-CF members, CCF members , and around 17 national FiA and FiA cantonment officials are members and invited to join. It#s expected that around 60participants,  of whom at least 25 is women, will be invited to join each of the meeting The purpose ofthe meeting is to review the progresses of the relevant issues/challenges raised in previous meeting(s) and discuss on new fisheries related issues, including illegal fishing activities, policies,#etc.Activity 2.1.4 (budget code 2.8) Conduct sub-nationalCFN meeting: FACT will coordinate to organize sub-  sub-national CFN meeting among NGO partners, CCF, and/or competent authorities (provincial FiA, authorities, policy, courts,#) to address the fisheries related issues at regional levels (Mekong, Tonle Sap, andcoastal). At least two meetings and 40 participants, of whom at least 10 is women, at each of the region will be organized. The main purpose of the meeting is address any fisheries related issues in which can be addressed at sub-national levelwithout bringing the issues to national level. There be at least 150 participants will be invited to join each forum.Activity 2.1.4 Conduct national round table/forum discussion: FACT will conduct one national public forum. The purpose of the forum is toshare fisheries related issues and together address the identified issues, in which can#t by addressed by and selected by CFN or NGO partners, among other multi-stakeholders such as FiA, MoE, MAFF, MoI, and court. The forum also aims at discussing onother legalframeworks such as amendment of Fisheries Law, Sub-degree on CFi management. There will be at least 60 participants will be invited to join this forum, of whom at least 25 is women.

title_narrative: Coordinated support to the NGO Forum members to improve and save lives
description_narrative:
The proposed project aims to contribute to effective and principled delivery of humanitarian assistance in South Sudan by national and international member organizations of the South Sudan NGO Forum in order to save lives and improve lives within the context of Revitalized Peace Agreement signed on September 12, 2018. Specifically, the project will work on various aspects of the creation of an ‘enabling environment’ for humanitarian assistance, namely: administrative, legal, political and security-related concerns, but also gaps in coordination and support to frontline engagement with authorities.

As a network and membership body of over 379 NGOs (263 NNGOs and 116 INGOs), the South Sudan NGO Forum provides a unique platform to promote safe and secure access providing capacity building for NGOs through providing humanitarian training sharing best practices in humanitarian delivery and information exchanges forging collaborations between the INGOs and national NGOs coordinating the collective voices of the NGOs for common positions ensuring accountability to effected populations the prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse and joint engagement for enabling environment for INGOs and NNGOs operating in South Sudan. The members of NGO Forum are present in all counties of South Sudan and deliver services across all sectors.

This project will allow the NGO Forum to continue to effectively support the NGO community in South Sudan by facilitating the protection of humanitarian space and respect for aid workers for improved delivery of humanitarian assistance to save and improved lives. The NGO Forum will strengthen and enhance coordination on issues of security, bureaucratic and access impediments and facilitate joint engagement with authorities, both national and local levels in tackling impediments that interfere with the effective delivery of services to the populations in need. The project will also focus on identifying and supporting referral pathways for the reporting of cases of sexual exploitation and abuse, and increasing the understanding across the sector of how to prevent or respond to cases.

The project will also support the review of the NGO Act 2016 to ensure humanitarian space and NGO space are protected for continued delivery of assistance to populations I need. In a similar vein the project will further support the development of information systems for NGO staffing with the national Ministry of Labour to help protect NGOs national staff whose positions are regularly politicized at field levels. This will provide national level assurance and protection of legally recruited NGO national staff.  

The NGO Forum has a 3-person security team at the national-level. To enhance the effectiveness of this team, in the interests of members, this project will help to project safety and security support and best practices to the states by providing safety, security and PSEA focal points who are focused on ensuring members are safe, able to operate effectively and within the guidelines of best practice, such as on PSEA.
The project will build on the improved relations with national level government authorities to improve relations with local authorities to reduce bureaucratic impediments and to improve acknowledgement of NGOs’ humanitarian identity and adherence to humanitarian principles and contribute to safe operating environments and allow access to populations in need of assistance. The project will facilitate workshops at national level with state agencies such as the Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs and the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission (RRC) to identify key issues affecting humanitarian agency operations. The state level workshops will be held with local authorities to discuss these issues affecting humanitarian programmes and solutions and action plans will be identified. COVID-19 awareness outreach information dissemination will be part and parcel of every engagements under project.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
other_identifier_owner_org_narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

title_narrative: South Sudan NGO Forum 2017-2020
NGO Forum Sydsudan 2017-2020
description_narrative: The intervention provides support for the South Sudan NGO Forum for the period 1 December 2017 to 31 August 2020. The NGO Forum is a member-based platform with more than 300 international and national NGO members in South Sudan. The NGO Forum's goal is to contribute to a more efficient and coordinated humanitarian and long-term development support in South Sudan. To achieve this, the NGO Forum Secretariat supoprts coordination, communication, advocacy, capacity development and security cooperation among the large number of NGOs delivering services and contributing to peace building and development in the country. Sida's assessment is that NGO Forum's activities, designed by the members during many years of cooperation, are relevant, effective and meet the needs of a changing and extremely challenging context. It is also Sida's assessment that the NGO Forum Secretariat has adequate capacity to carry out its activities and that the Concern Worldwide (as a host organisation/fund administrator of the secretariat) is a reliable partner.

Insatsen utgör ett stöd till South Sudan NGO Forum för perioden 1 december 2017-31 augusti 2020. NGO Forum utgör en medlemsbaserad plattform med drygt 300 internationella och nationella icke-statliga organisationer i Sydsudan. NGO Forums mål är att bidra till ett mer effektivt och samordnat humanitärt och långsiktigt utvecklingsstöd i Sydsudan. För att uppnå detta stödjer NGO Forums sekretariat samordning, kommunikation, påverksansarbete, kapacitetsutveckling, samt säkerhetssamarbete bland det stora antal NGO:er som levererar service och bidrar till fredsbyggande och utveckling i landet. Det är Sidas bedömning att NGO Forums verksamhet, som utformats av medlemmarna under många års samarbete, är relevant, effektiv och motsvarar behoven i en föränderlig och synnerligen utmanande kontext. Det är även Sidas bedömning att NGO Forums sekretariat har erfoderlig kapacitet att fortsätta genomföra dess aktiviteter. samt att Concern Worldwide (som värdorganisation/fondadministratör för sekreteriatet) utgör en tillförlitlig samarbetspartner.

The expected outcome is "Improved international and national non-governmental organisation (NGO) engagement in South Sudan in the delivery of humanitarian and development assistance". The expected impact is "Effective and principled delivery of humanitarian and development assistance by NGOs South Sudan".

reporting_org_narrative: Sweden
result_description_narrative: The activities of the NGO Forum are grouped in four clusters. Examples of results under each cluster are: Information Sharing and Coordination: Support to members in their information sharing and coordination role through sharing of 54 Country/National Director weekly updates, 10 circulars and 27 legislation documents via the NGO forum communication portal during the period September 2019 - February 2020. During the same period NGO Forum's online web resources recorded a total of 6,8 million unique page views serving over 117,000 users, ranking the website among the most visited sites in South Sudan. Safety, Security and Crisis Management: From September 2019 to February 2020, the NGO Forum Security Team coordinated the relocation of 198 NGO workers through the Saving Lives Together (SLT) framework with the support of UNHAS,WFP, UNDSS and OCHA. Under SLT there were 392 information exchanges and meetings held between NGO Forum and UNDSS/UNMISS. The Security Team also provided security incident datatsets and area profiles on request. Advocacy, Policy and External Engagement: NGO Forum has broadened its relationships and engagement with ministries and authorities of all parties to the conflict, in order to support Forum members to access beneficiaries without hindrance, or resolve impediments when they arise (for example relating to tax issues). This has reduced costs to NGOs and the wider humanitarian community in operations, financial, human resource and time terms and has helped bring about increased clarity and understanding in the operating environment.  NGO's Networking and Capacity Development: From September 2019 to February 2020,  NGO Forum through its Focal Point member CIPAD provided gender mainstreaming, Prevention of Sexual Exploitation and Abuse (PSEA) and trauma healing strategies training to 60 NGOs in Juba. Through this initiative the NGO Forum also developed a model PSEA policy and code of conduct that the NGO Forum has asked national NGOs to adopt and adapt for use and opeartionalise.

It is also Sida's assessment that the NGO Forum Secretariat has adequate capacity to carry out its activities and that the Concern Worldwide (as a host organisation/fund administrator of the secretariat) is a reliable partner.

Insatsen utgör ett stöd till South Sudan NGO Forum för perioden 1 december 2017-31 augusti 2020. NGO Forum utgör en medlemsbaserad plattform med drygt 300 internationella och nationella icke-statliga organisationer i Sydsudan. NGO Forums mål är att bidra till ett mer effektivt och samordnat humanitärt och långsiktigt utvecklingsstöd i Sydsudan. För att uppnå detta stödjer NGO Forums sekretariat samordning, kommunikation, påverksansarbete, kapacitetsutveckling, samt säkerhetssamarbete bland det stora antal NGO:er som levererar service och bidrar till fredsbyggande och utveckling i landet. Det är Sidas bedömning att NGO Forums verksamhet, som utformats av medlemmarna under många års samarbete, är relevant, effektiv och motsvarar behoven i en föränderlig och synnerligen utmanande kontext. Det är även Sidas bedömning att NGO Forums sekretariat har erfoderlig kapacitet att fortsätta genomföra dess aktiviteter. samt att Concern Worldwide (som värdorganisation/fondadministratör för sekreteriatet) utgör en tillförlitlig samarbetspartner.

The expected outcome is "Improved international and national non-governmental organisation (NGO) engagement in South Sudan in the delivery of humanitarian and development assistance". The expected impact is "Effective and principled delivery of humanitarian and development assistance by NGOs South Sudan".

result_description_narrative: The activities of the NGO Forum are grouped in four clusters. Examples of results under each cluster are: Information Sharing and Coordination: Support to members in their information sharing and coordination role through sharing of 54 Country/National Director weekly updates, 10 circulars and 27 legislation documents via the NGO forum communication portal during the period September 2019 - February 2020. During the same period NGO Forum's online web resources recorded a total of 6,8 million unique page views serving over 117,000 users, ranking the website among the most visited sites in South Sudan. Safety, Security and Crisis Management: From September 2019 to February 2020, the NGO Forum Security Team coordinated the relocation of 198 NGO workers through the Saving Lives Together (SLT) framework with the support of UNHAS,WFP, UNDSS and OCHA. Under SLT there were 392 information exchanges and meetings held between NGO Forum and UNDSS/UNMISS. The Security Team also provided security incident datatsets and area profiles on request. Advocacy, Policy and External Engagement: NGO Forum has broadened its relationships and engagement with ministries and authorities of all parties to the conflict, in order to support Forum members to access beneficiaries without hindrance, or resolve impediments when they arise (for example relating to tax issues). This has reduced costs to NGOs and the wider humanitarian community in operations, financial, human resource and time terms and has helped bring about increased clarity and understanding in the operating environment.  NGO's Networking and Capacity Development: From September 2019 to February 2020,  NGO Forum through its Focal Point member CIPAD provided gender mainstreaming, Prevention of Sexual Exploitation and Abuse (PSEA) and trauma healing strategies training to 60 NGOs in Juba. Through this initiative the NGO Forum also developed a model PSEA policy and code of conduct that the NGO Forum has asked national NGOs to adopt and adapt for use and opeartionalise.

title_narrative: Coordinated support to the NGO Forum members to improve and save lives
description_narrative:
The proposed project aims to contribute to effective and principled delivery of humanitarian assistance in South Sudan by national and international member organisations of the South Sudan NGO Forum in order to save lives and improve lives within the context of Revitalised Peace Agreement signed on September 12, 2018. As a network and membership body of over 330 NGOs (214 national NGOs and 116 international NGOs), the South Sudan NGO Forum provides a unique platform for inducting NGO Country Directors into the regulatory environment of South Sudan facilitating networking among members and with Government and UN Agencies providing capacity building for NGOs through providing humanitarian training sharing best practices in humanitarian delivery and information exchanges forging collaborations between the INGOs and national NGOs coordinating the collective voices of the NGOs for common positions and joint advocacy for enabling environment for INGOs and NNGOs operating in South Sudan. The members of NGO Forum are present in all counties of South Sudan and deliver services across all sectors.

This project will allow the NGO Forum to continue to effectively support the NGO community in South Sudan by facilitating the protection of humanitarian space and respect for aid workers for improved delivery of humanitarian assistance to save and improved lives. The NGO Forum will strengthen and enhance coordination on issues of security, bureaucratic and access impediments and facilitate joint engagement with authorities, both national and local levels in tackling impediments that interfere with the effective delivery of services to the populations in need. The project will build on the improved relations with national level government authorities to improve relations with local authorities to reduce bureaucratic impediments and to improve acknowledgement of NGOs’ humanitarian identify and adherence to humanitarian principles and contribute to safe operating environments and allow access to populations in need of assistance. The project will facilitate workshops at national level with state agencies such as the Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs and the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission (RRC) to identify key issues affecting humanitarian agency operations. The state level workshops will be held with local authorities to discuss these issues affecting humanitarian programmes and solutions and action plans will be identified.

title_narrative: NCCI Bureaucratic Liaison Unit
description_narrative:
The Bureaucratic Liaison Unit (BLU) project aims to lead the work of the NGO forum on issues related to government legislation and regulations affecting work of NGOs in Iraq, such that NGOs are more effectively able to deliver humanitarian, post-emergency and early recovery programming for millions of Iraqis in need.  
Most importantly, the BLU will act as an information resource for NGOs regarding the relevant and updated procedures, contacts and best practice for NGOs for: registration, visas, taxes, importation, reporting and other administrative services and requirements with the authorities in central and northern Iraq. To do so, the BLU will provide relevant legal and regulatory information in English and Arabic, as well as templates, contact lists and associated costs for service providers and procedures. With support from NCCI’s Information Management Unit, the BLU will develop guidance material to support NGO relationships with primary government counterparts as identified and directed by the NCCI Executive Board and Executive Director. The BLU will serve as a guide to NGOs regarding the official and unofficial best practices regarding the bureaucracy in Iraq and provide bilateral and coordinated responses to enquiries.
The BLU will develop and maintain productive relationships with relevant actors, including the local authorities, United Nations and diplomatic community. In particular, local and high level liaison with national and regional authorities will enable timely information gathering and analysis of opportunities for advocacy. The BLU will facilitate strategic engagement and timely information sharing between the NGO forum with Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator and UN Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), contributing to an effective partnership in support of NGOs operating in Iraq.
The BLU will track the trends and impact of bureaucratic impediments on NGO operations, through regular surveys or other appropriate means, in order to enable timely and targeted advocacy with authorities and influencers.
The BLU will ensure strong linkages within the forum groups to enable strategic engagement and advocacy by the Executive Board, Executive Director, Advocacy Coordinator and HR/Admin Working Group. Provision of regular information to the designated leads for inclusion in relevant working groups, external meetings and advocacy engagement of the NGO Steering Committee will allow NCCI’s capacity to deliver the required support.
With a mandate for service provision, the Bureaucratic Liaison Unit will:
	Maintain an accessible repository of laws, regulations, circulars and other government instructions that are relevant to the work of NGOs in Iraq
	Be familiar with the content of laws, regulations, circulars and other government instructions that are relevant to the work of NGOs in Iraq, in order to advise NGOs of the existence of relevant clauses. (However, interpretation and application of such clauses is left to the responsibility of individual NGOs and their legal advisers).
	Collect, analyze and disseminate information on trends and impact of regulations and procedures on NGO operations, including through position papers and information management products.
	Enable timely and effective advocacy by NCCI groups and members, such that the regulatory environment facilitates NGOs to deliver assistance at scale and according to vulnerability.
	Contribute to NGO engagement with the government and other key stakeholders regarding the development of laws and regulations that affect the work of NGOs in Iraq (through, for example, tracking how issues are affecting NGOs, developing appropriate briefing papers, and attending relevant meetings).
	As directed by the Executive Director and the Executive Board, map, develop and maintain contacts with key government staff/advisors involved in regulatory issues affecting NGOs, in order to keep updated on regulations and

title_narrative: Equipping Pangolin Range States to Better Implement CITES and Combat Wildlife Trafficking Through Developing Monitoring Methodologies
description_narrative: 'The purpose of this project is to equip pangolin range states to better implement CITES and combat wildlife trafficking, through developing species specific monitoring methodologies. This project is intended to conserve pangolins by developing monitoring methods that should enable angolin range states to more effectively determine the status of pangolins populations; to identify priority areas for their conservation; and to better protect populations from wildlife trafficking. Specific activities include: (1) conduct systematic literature reviews on pangolin ecology, biology and natural history and monitoring methods used to date, and on methods used to monitor ecologically similar species; (2) develop a questionnaire on potentially new, existing and adapted methodologies for monitoring pangolin populations to be completed by IUCN SSC Pangolin Specialist Group members and a wide range of biodiversity survey experts globally; (3) using the results of the literature reviews and questionnaire, hold a 3 day workshop to develop methodologies for each of the eight species of pangolin, focusing on (i) being able to determine presence of pangolins at the site level, and (ii) being able to undertake long-term monitoring of populations; (4) produce guidance documents on the methods developed for dissemination to CITES Parties and other stakeholders; (5) document the methods developed in peer-reviewed scientific journal publications; and (6) present the methods developed at the next available CITES meeting.. title_narrative: UGANDA NATIONAL NGO FORUM
sector_narrative: The right to life and security
description_narrative: Uganda National NGO Forum was launched in 1997 following two years of concerted work to develop the operational structure, a Constitution and membership recruitment program. Many NGOs had realised the need to engage Government and the donor community on policy issues and poverty concerns. Also, Government found it increasingly important to involve Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) in the design and implementation of policies and programmes.The idea to form UNNGOF was to establish an organization that would wholly represent CSOs while bringing together National NGOs, International NGOs, CBOs, Voluntary Development Organizations (VDOs), and Farmers# Groups, Cooperative Associations and other Citizens# Organizations and interest groups from all thematic areas.The first General Assembly of UNNGOF was held in January of 1997 after nationwide sensitization and mass mobilization. About 1,000 NGO representatives participated and it was agreed that the Forum would create a comprehensive membership base that would meet periodically to choose and renew leadership and other governance organs in a democratic manner. Since then, UNNGOF has never wavered in providing a platform and leadership for CSOs on behalf of the poor and through time, created a neutral ground for all NGOs to constructively interact.By 2001, UNNGOF had established policies and procedures for accountability, established formal registration for members, operationaliseda code of conduct, amended the Constitution by re-mobilizing members, developed a three year rights-based Strategic Plan, and set up district forums for support at district level and to the Secretariat.Currently, UNNGOF brings together 630 member organizations across the country. As a platform organization, UNNGOF has over the last 20 years UNNGOF has built capacity to convene diverse organizations to work on various collective initiatives. Further, it has also established itself as a credible partner with various government agencies where it plays a representational role forcivil society. Gender integration is an issue that we take seriously and forall our program activities we ensure that women and men are well represented.2. ACHIEVEMENTSWhat have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion?Coordinating Civil Society Policy AdvocacyOver the last three years, there was increased participation of civil society in policy formulation. The first ever monitoring survey of the Vision 2040 was launched in 2014 and reached over 1000 households through the national survey in all districts of Uganda. UNNGOF coordinated Civil society input in the development of the second National Development Plan and over 10 issues papers were shared with the government. UNNGOF worked closely with civil society in the post 2015 agenda that led to the development of the Sustainable Development Goals. This process reached over 4000 citizens across Uganda and civil society voice was present in the global collective messaging on the post 2015 agenda in New York as well as civil society work nationally. This work has anchored UNNGOF in the policy arena inUganda. This is evident from UNNGOF#s representational role on major policy committees in the Office of the Prime Minister, National Planning Authority and Ministry of Gender, Labour and Social development.Supporting the work of Sub-National Civil SocietyUNNGOFhas offered leadership to civil Society at the sub-national level through the collective organizing around civil society issues of a cross cutting nature. We have been instrumental in bringing together civil society under campaigns like Black Mondayand the development of the National Development Plan as well as linking civil society to national policy agenda. The sub-national level today boasts of several organisations that are seen as strong Civil society leaders in their regions with most of themlinked to the investmentand partnership that UNNGOF has developed through the support to Advocacy Networks infrastructure as well as the work we have continued to spearhead under the Citizen Manifesto.Civic engagement on Civic SpaceUNNGOF has been aproactive convener and interlocutorin many processes hat bring together Civil Society and decision makers at various levels. At the local level , the citizen manifesto has provided such a space for citizen-leader interactions. At the national level we have been instrumental in convening meetings between the Minster of Internal affairs and civil society leaders on several topical issues. These processes have created avenues forbuilding confidence among civil society and government and political leaders onmatters of mutual interest.3.    INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSEMission: What is the current purpose of the organisation?To provide a sharing and reflection platform for Non-governmental Organisations (NGOs) to influence governance and development processes in Uganda and enhance their operating environment.Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term?a) A strong and well coordinated civil society sector with information and capacity to effectively engage in and contribute to development processes.b) Citizens with a greater awareness of their own situation, mobilised, informed and actively participating in policy, governance and development processes.c) Civic space and CSO operating environment influenced positively at the local and global level and influencing citizen engagement in governance processes.d) Citizen responsive government policy and practice alternatives generated through evidence building and advocacy at all levels.e) A dynamic UNNGOF identity and presence built in Uganda and across East Africa and globally through our results, learning and communication as well imaginative knowledge brokering.f) Cost-efficient support to the secretariat that fosters an institutional culture of optimal re-source use that better enables UNNGOF to accomplish its objectives.Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works?  Who are the social actors that benefit from the work?UNNGOF is a national platform and its work is anchored on two broad intervention areas of civil society strengthening and Influencing Development Policy and Practice. We therefore undertake activities in three complementary program components. Thesecomponents are supported by two functions which include; a) Results, learning and Communication and b) Corporate ServicesPolicy Advocacy and State Engagement Under this programme component, we focus on effectively coordinating NGOs engagement on multi-stakeholder and multi-sectoral policy processes-NDPs, National Level Budget Analysis, Aid and Development Effectiveness, 2030 Agenda and EAC among others.Civic Space and governance monitoring. This component area we seek to influence internal and external operating environment issues of CSOs and ensure a positive environment for NGO operations and citizen engagement in governance processes. The focus is on coordination of NGO legislation efforts; promoting enabling environment and monitoring governanceprocesses through initiative like the Citizen Manifesto-Civil Society Strengthening Under this intervention area, UNNGOF will continue to provide capacity development initiatives in several ways. These will include; work related to strengthening BoardsofDirectors of CSOs organizations, work with Women Leaders in civil society as well as general capacity development work for organizations.  Evaluation results of the last strategic plan indicate that there is a need for more innovation in the area ofcapacity development so that it creates more impact and is more relevant to our members and constituencies.  We shall, therefore, seek to develop initiatives with universities and otherinstitutions of higher learning.While UNNGOF is a national platform, italso hosts the Support Program for Advocacy Networks that brings together 35 District Networks with a combined reach to 3000 civil society organizations across the country.  The infrastructure described above gives us the leverage to be able to reach millions and work with a diversity of organizations including those in underserved areas.4. STRATEGIC POSITIONINGAnalyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? In this context, what is unique about the position of theorganisation?UNNGOF operates in an environment where citizens are debased as these focus on individual politicians rather than public service delivery institutions. This focuson individuals rather than institutions fuels both political patronage and elite patronage which affects quality service delivery and government accountability.For civil society, these challenges constrain civil space and citizen participationin state politics and lead to the emergence of a #debased citizenry#. The effect of this individual merit hangover on Uganda#s citizen-state relationship is therefore a context that limits citizen engagement, participation and even appreciation of political diversity.UNNGOF has a number of partners and collaborators and these include; District Networks - collaborate in the area of programming and expanding our work to reach millions of citizens; National Networks and NGOs - collective advocacy on issues of national interest - like the National Budget, the NGO Law, the Sustainable Development Goals and the Vision 2040; Media-toamplify our voice and disseminate our issues to all partners in government and outside government; Citizen groups: Get feedbackon issues that affect their livelihood to be relayed to policy makers and implementers and Government which is a key advocacy target forour work on influencing development policies and practice.UNNGOF#s niche is its character. UNNGOF is a platform anda leaderin collective advocacy initiatives.  While many organizations can do policy advocacy, it takes organizations with the capacity to convene other organizations to have an impact on government policies that are nation-wide.  As a platform organization we aretherefore the #go-to# organization for Government institutions, civil society organizations, donors and citizens group that would like to generate collective positions, engage in coordinated collective advocacy and for reaching millions of citizens.  Italso plays a representational role for civil society in a number of state institutions such as   the National Planning Authority, Office of the Prime Minister implementation committees, the Accountability Sector Working Group and the  Ministry of Gender,Labourand Social Development.

INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSEMission: What is the current purpose of the organisation?To provide a sharing and reflection platform for Non-governmental Organisations (NGOs) to influence governance and development processes in Uganda and enhance their operating environment.Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term?a) A strong and well coordinated civil society sector with information and capacity to effectively engage in and contribute to development processes.b) Citizens with a greater awareness of their own situation, mobilised, informed and actively participating in policy, governance and development processes.c) Civic space and CSO operating environment influenced positively at the local and global level and influencing citizen engagement in governance processes.d) Citizen responsive government policy and practice alternatives generated through evidence building and advocacy at all levels.e) A dynamic UNNGOF identity and presence built in Uganda and across East Africa and globally through our results, learning and communication as well imaginative knowledge brokering.f) Cost-efficient support to the secretariat that fosters an institutional culture of optimal re-source use that better enables UNNGOF to accomplish its objectives.Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works?  Who are the social actors that benefit from the work?UNNGOF is a national platform and its work is anchored on two broad intervention areas of civil society strengthening and Influencing Development Policy and Practice. We therefore undertake activities in three complementary program components. These components are supported by two functions which include; a) Results, learning and Communication and b) Corporate ServicesPolicy Advocacy and State Engagement Under this programme component, we focus on effectively coordinating NGOs engagement on multi-stakeholder and multi-sectoral policy processes-NDPs, National Level Budget Analysis, Aid and Development Effectiveness, 2030 Agenda and EACamong others.Civic Space and governance monitoring. This component area we seek to influence internal and external operating environment issues of CSOs and ensure a positive environment for NGO operations and citizen engagement in governance processes. The focusis on coordination of NGO legislation efforts; promoting enabling environment and monitoring governance processes through initiative like the Citizen Manifesto-Civil Society Strengthening Under this intervention area, UNNGOF will continue to provide capacity development initiatives in several ways. These will include; work related to strengthening Boards of Directors of CSOs organizations, work with Women Leaders in civil society as well as general capacity development work for organizations.  Evaluation results of the last strategic plan indicate that there is a need for more innovation in the area ofcapacity development so that it creates more impact and is more relevant to our members and constituencies.  We shall, therefore, seek to develop initiatives with universities and other institutions of higher learning.While UNNGOF is a national platform, italso hosts the Support Program for Advocacy Networks that brings together 35 District Networks with a combined reach to 3000 civil society organizations across the country.  The infrastructure described above gives us the leverage to be able to reach millions and work with a diversity of organizations including those in underserved areas.4. STRATEGIC POSITIONINGAnalyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? In this context, what is unique about the position ofthe organisation?UNNGOF operates in an environment where citizens are debased as these focus on individual politicians rather thanpublic service delivery institutions. This focus on individuals rather than institutions fuels both political patronage and elite patronage which affects quality service delivery and government accountability.For civil society, these challenges constrain civil space and citizen participationin state politics and lead to the emergence of a #debased citizenry#. The effect of this individual merit hangover on Uganda#s citizen-state relationship is therefore a context that limits citizen engagement, participation and even appreciation of political diversity.UNNGOF has a number of partners and collaborators and these include; District Networks - collaborate in the area of programming and expanding our work to reach millions of citizens; National Networks and NGOs - collective advocacy on issues of national interest - like the National Budget, the NGO Law, the Sustainable Development Goals and the Vision 2040; Media-to amplify our voice and disseminate our issues to all partners in government and outside government; Citizen groups: Get feedbackon issues that affect their livelihood to be relayed to policy makers and implementers and Government which is a key advocacy target for our work on influencing development policies and practice.UNNGOF#s niche is its character. UNNGOF is a platform anda leaderincollective advocacy initiatives.  While many organizations can do policy advocacy, it takes organizations with the capacity to convene other organizations to have an impact on government policies that are nation-wide.  As a platform organization we aretherefore the #go-to# organization for Government institutions, civil society organizations, donors and citizens group that would like to generate collective positions, engage in coordinated collective advocacy and for reaching millions of citizens.  Italso plays a representational role for civil society in a number of state institutions such as   the National Planning Authority, Office of the Prime Minister implementation committees, the Accountability Sector Working Group and the  Ministry of Gender,Labour and Social Development.

description_narrative: Uganda National NGO Forum was launched in 1997 following two years of concerted work to develop the operational structure, a Constitution and membership recruitment program. About 1,000 NGO representatives participated and it was agreed that the Forum would create a comprehensive membership base that would meet periodically to choose and renew leadership and other governance organs in a democratic manner. Since then, UNNGOF has never wavered in providing a platform and leadership for CSOs on behalf of the poor and through time, created a neutral ground for all NGOs to constructively interact.By 2001, UNNGOF had established policies and procedures for accountability, established formal registration for members, operationaliseda code of conduct, amended the Constitution by re-mobilizing members, developed a three year rights-based Strategic Plan, and set up district forums for support at district level and to the Secretariat.Currently, UNNGOF brings together 630 member organizations across the country. participating_org_narrative: UGANDA NATIONAL NGO FORUM NGO FORUM

Uganda National NGO Forum was launched in 1997 following two years of concerted work to develop the operational structure, a Constitution and membership recruitment program. Many NGOs had realised the need to engage Government and the donor community on policy issues and poverty concerns. Also, Government found it increasingly important to involve Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) in the design and implementation of policies and programmes.The idea to form UNNGOF was to establish an organization that would wholly represent CSOs while bringing together National NGOs, International NGOs, CBOs, Voluntary Development Organizations (VDOs), and Farmers# Groups, Cooperative Associations and other Citizens# Organizations and interest groups from all thematic areas.The first General Assembly of UNNGOF was held in January of 1997 after nationwide sensitization and mass mobilization. About 1,000 NGO representatives participated and it was agreed that the Forum would create a comprehensive membership base that would meet periodically to choose and renew leadership and other governance organs in a democratic manner. Since then, UNNGOF has never wavered in providing a platform and leadership for CSOs on behalf of the poor and through time, created a neutral ground for all NGOs to constructively interact.By 2001, UNNGOF had established policies and procedures for accountability, established formal registration for members, operationaliseda code of conduct, amended the Constitution by re-mobilizing members, developed a three year rights-based Strategic Plan, and set up district forums for support at district level and to the Secretariat.Currently, UNNGOF brings together 630 member organizations across the country. As a platform organization, UNNGOF has over the last 20 years UNNGOF has built capacity to convene diverse organizations to work on various collective initiatives. Further, it has also established itself as a credible partner with various government agencies where it plays a representational role forcivil society. Gender integration is an issue that we take seriously and forall our program activities we ensure that women and men are well represented.2. ACHIEVEMENTSWhat have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion?Coordinating Civil Society Policy AdvocacyOver the last three years, there was increased participation of civil society in policy formulation. The first ever monitoring survey of the Vision 2040 was launched in 2014 and reached over 1000 households through the national survey in all districts of Uganda. UNNGOF coordinated Civil society input in the development of the second National Development Plan and over 10 issues papers were shared with the government. UNNGOF worked closely with civil society in the post 2015 agenda that led to the development of the Sustainable Development Goals. This process reached over 4000 citizens across Uganda and civil society voice was present in the global collective messaging on the post 2015 agenda in New York as well as civil society work nationally. This work has anchored UNNGOF in the policy arena inUganda. This is evident from UNNGOF#s representational role on major policy committees in the Office of the Prime Minister, National Planning Authority and Ministry of Gender, Labour and Social development.Supporting the work of Sub-National Civil SocietyUNNGOFhas offered leadership to civil Society at the sub-national level through the collective organizing around civil society issues of a cross cutting nature. We have been instrumental in bringing together civil society under campaigns like Black Mondayand the development of the National Development Plan as well as linking civil society to national policy agenda. The sub-national level today boasts of several organisations that are seen as strong Civil society leaders in their regions with most of themlinked to the investmentand partnership that UNNGOF has developed through the support to Advocacy Networks infrastructure as well as the work we have continued to spearhead under the Citizen Manifesto.Civic engagement on Civic SpaceUNNGOF has been aproactive convener and interlocutor in many processes hat bring together Civil Society and decision makers at various levels. At the local level , the citizen manifestohas provided such a space for citizen-leader interactions. At the national level we have been instrumental in convening meetings between the Minster of Internal affairs and civil society leaders on several topical issues. These processes have created avenues for building confidence among civil society and government and political leaders on matters of mutual interest.3.    INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSEMission: What is the current purpose of the organisation?To provide a sharing and reflection platform for Non-governmental Organisations (NGOs) to influence governance and development processes in Uganda and enhance their operating environment.Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term?a) A strong and well coordinated civil society sector with information and capacity to effectively engage in and contribute to development processes.b) Citizens with a greater awareness of their own situation, mobilised, informed and actively participating in policy, governance and development processes.c) Civic space and CSO operating environment influenced positively at the local and global level and influencing citizen engagement in governance processes.d) Citizen responsive government policy and practice alternatives generated through evidence building and advocacy at all levels.e) A dynamic UNNGOF identity and presence built in Uganda and across East Africa and globally through our results, learning and communication as well imaginative knowledge brokering.f) Cost-efficient support to the secretariat that fosters an institutional culture of optimal re-source use that better enables UNNGOF to accomplish its objectives.Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works?  Who are the social actors that benefit from the work?UNNGOF is a national platform and its work is anchored on two broad intervention areas of civil society strengthening and Influencing Development Policy and Practice. We therefore undertake activities in three complementary program components. These components are supported by two functions which include; a) Results, learning and Communication and b) Corporate ServicesPolicy Advocacy and State Engagement Under this programme component, we focus on effectively coordinating NGOs engagement on multi-stakeholder and multi-sectoral policy processes-NDPs, National Level Budget Analysis, Aid and Development Effectiveness, 2030 Agenda and EACamong others.Civic Space and governance monitoring. This component area we seek to influence internal and external operating environment issues of CSOs and ensure a positive environment for NGO operations and citizen engagement in governance processes. The focusis on coordination of NGO legislation efforts; promoting enabling environment and monitoring governance processes through initiative like the Citizen Manifesto-Civil Society Strengthening Under this intervention area, UNNGOF will continue to provide capacity development initiatives in several ways. These will include; work related to strengthening Boards of Directors of CSOs organizations, work with Women Leaders in civil society as well as general capacity development work for organizations.  Evaluation results of the last strategic plan indicate that there is a need for more innovation in the area ofcapacity development so that it creates more impact and is more relevant to our members and constituencies.  We shall, therefore, seek to develop initiatives with universities and other institutions of higher learning.While UNNGOF is a national platform, italso hosts the Support Program for Advocacy Networks that brings together 35 District Networks with a combined reach to 3000 civil society organizations across the country.  The infrastructure described above gives us the leverage to be able to reach millions and work with a diversity of organizations including those in underserved areas.4. STRATEGIC POSITIONINGAnalyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? In this context, what is unique about the position ofthe organisation?UNNGOF operates in an environment where citizens are debased as these focus on individual politicians rather thanpublic service delivery institutions. This focus on individuals rather than institutions fuels both political patronage and elite patronage which affects quality service delivery and government accountability.For civil society, these challenges constrain civil space and citizen participationin state politics and lead to the emergence of a #debased citizenry#. The effect of this individual merit hangover on Uganda#s citizen-state relationship is therefore a context that limits citizen engagement, participation and even appreciation of political diversity.UNNGOF has a number of partners and collaborators and these include; District Networks - collaborate in the area of programming and expanding our work to reach millions of citizens; National Networks and NGOs - collective advocacy on issues of national interest - like the National Budget, the NGO Law, the Sustainable Development Goals and the Vision 2040; Media-to amplify our voice and disseminate our issues to all partners in government and outside government; Citizen groups: Get feedbackon issues that affect their livelihood to be relayed to policy makers and implementers and Government which is a key advocacy target for our work on influencing development policies and practice.UNNGOF#s niche is its character. UNNGOF is a platform anda leaderincollective advocacy initiatives.  While many organizations can do policy advocacy, it takes organizations with the capacity to convene other organizations to have an impact on government policies that are nation-wide.  As a platform organization we aretherefore the #go-to# organization for Government institutions, civil society organizations, donors and citizens group that would like to generate collective positions, engage in coordinated collective advocacy and for reaching millions of citizens.  Italso plays a representational role for civil society in a number of state institutions such as   the National Planning Authority, Office of the Prime Minister implementation committees, the Accountability Sector Working Group and the  Ministry of Gender,Labour and Social Development.

title_narrative: NCCI Bureaucratic Liaison Unit -- Year 2
description_narrative:
A clear and practical regulatory environment is critical to principled humanitarian access and programming. NGOs working in Iraq have regularly cited access, a lack of regulatory clarity, inconsistencies in the application of regulations, frequent procedural changes, and overlapping jurisdictions as impediments, which constrain humanitarian space and create challenges that cause delays to implementation and increase operational costs.
BLU was founded in 2018 to advocate for the regulatory and operational space that allows NGOs to operate in Iraq. The unit is a leading information resource, providing relevant and updated information to members. BLU has fostered high-level relationships with relevant actors, including the central and local authorities in the GOI and KRI, the UN and the diplomatic community. Since early 2019, BLU has increasingly focused on access related issues.  
This project will extend BLU’s operations for one year. In 2019, NCCI will scale up work on access and field level constraints in close collaboration with the Access Working Group (AWG) while continuing to address the many other regulatory impediments. BLU will work with the authorities and other external actors to understand and communicate changing policies and practices to the NGO community. BLU will track, report and analyse NGO challenges and communicate concerns to government stakeholders. NCCI’s advocacy, knowledge management and coordination capacity will continue to help the NGO community maintain and expand humanitarian access.
While many impediments arise unexpectedly, in 2019, BLU will prioritise NGO-oriented solutions to bureaucratic impediments, including working closely with the central and governorate-levels government and other external actors to understand and communicate changing regulatory policies and practices to the NGO community. 
	Access: Acceptance of Access Letters in federal Iraq is inconsistent and continues to pose a challenge. Local actors, notably in Ninawa, have demonstrated a reluctance to accept letters issued by the JCMC. It is anticipated that this trend will continue with a spill-over to other governorates. BLU is working closely with the AWG and member NGOs, including relevant heads of base, to ensure a unified response. BLU’s engagement with the central government has already resulted in positive change in the Access Letter application process. NCCI’s advocacy with DNGO has brought the issue to the attention of the Secretary-General of COMSEC. BLU will increase its high-level engagement with the central and local authorities, and NGO heads of base, to find a workable solution. Blue will also submit all reported access incident to the AWG matrix.
	GoI Visas: BLU will continue to advocate for a faster and more streamlined visa issuance process including. clarity in the visa renewal process.
	Hiring quotas: Government officials, particularly in KRI, continue to pressure NGOs to comply with certain staff quotas. BLU will continue to advocate for principled humanitarian policies and regulations that are inclusive to all ethnicities.
	Work permits: MOLSA has asked NGOs to apply for work permits for their expat staff at a cost of 1000 USD per employee per year. BLU is working with the DNGO and MOLSA to obtain an exemption for expat NGO staff.
	Tax and customs: BLU will continue working with relevant government institutions on NGO compliance with tax, customs and transport regulations and to ensure the uninterrupted movement of goods and cargo from the KRI into GoI. 
	Registration: The GOI registration process is cumbersome and can take in excess of one year. In May 2019, DNGO announced that it would no longer issue temporary registrations. BLU will advocate with DNGO to reconsider its decision.
	Residency restrictions on shared office space: As a result of our engagement, Residency has temporarily suspended restrictions on NGO collocation. BLU will advocate for this to become permenant.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative:
Capacity Development in Mineral Resources Economics of the Mineral
        Resources Authority of Mongolia (MRAM)

Rohstoffwirtschaftliche Kapazitätenentwicklung der Behörde für
        mineralische Rohstoffe der Mongolei
description_narrative:
The project supports the state mining authority of Mongolia (Mineral
        Resources Authority of Mongolia, MRAM), in order to increase their capacity as professional
        service provider for the Mongolian mineral resources sector and thereby complying with their
        mandate to regulate and promote the sector. Strengthening the expertise of MRAM will happen
        in the fields of activity (1) evaluation of mineral deposits and occurrences, (2)
        elaboration of regional or global oriented economic analyses on Mongolian mining products,
        and (3) the enhancement of the in-house integrated data management system (IMS) for the
        organization of mineral resource and mining related data as well as the management of
        exploration and mining licenses.

Das Vorhaben unterstützt die staatliche Bergbaubehörde der Mongolei
        (Mineral Resources Authority of Mongolia, MRAM) in deren Bemühungen, sich als kompetente
        Dienstleisterin für den mongolischen Rohstoffsektor aufzustellen und somit das Mandat zur
        Regulierung und Förderung des Sektors zu erfüllen. Die Kompetenzstärkung umfasst die drei
        Aufgabenbereichen (1) Evaluierung von Lagerstätten, (2) Durchführen regional und global
        ausgerichteter Marktanalysen für die mongolischen Bergbauprodukte, und (3) Ausbau eines
        integrierten Datenbanksystems für die Verwaltung von rohstoff- und bergwirtschaftlichen
        Daten sowie der Explorations- und Abbaulizenzen.

The project supports the state mining authority of Mongolia (Mineral
        Resources Authority of Mongolia, MRAM), in order to increase their capacity as professional
        service provider for the Mongolian mineral resources sector and thereby complying with their
        mandate to regulate and promote the sector. Strengthening the expertise of MRAM will happen
        in the fields of activity (1) evaluation of mineral deposits and occurrences, (2)
        elaboration of regional or global oriented economic analyses on Mongolian mining products,
        and (3) the enhancement of the in-house integrated data management system (IMS) for the
        organization of mineral resource and mining related data as well as the management of
        exploration and mining licenses.

MRAM ist dazu in der Lage, fachgerechte Informationen für den
        privaten und staatlichen mineralischen Rohstoffsektor der Mongolei bereit zu
        stellen.
