title_narrative: Production of high quality plastic packaging for the Angolan market
description_narrative: Plastic Packaging (Pty) Ltd from Namibia is a producer and supplier of polyethylene products as carrier bags, refuse bags, heavy duty bags, shrink sheets etc. Customers of these products are from the meat and fishing industry, the wholesale and retail industry. During the years, they have established several daughter companies and joint ventures (e.g. in South Africa).During the late 1990s, Plastic Packaging (Pty) Ltd expanded its activities to Angola and its daughter in Angola, Ango Plasticos Lda was established, with headquarters in Lubango (Southern Angola). Apart from that, also four branch offices for sales and distribution were established in Angola. Presently, all products sold in Angola are imported from Namibia.In order toa) meet the growing market demand,b) reduce the costs (transport and import duties) andc) become less dependent of the South African rand,the management of Ango Plasticos Lda would like to establish an own production facility in Angola (Lubango) to serve the Angolan market directly. This market (retailers, manufacturers, agricultural and fish process industries) demand more and more diversified and tailor-made packaging products.The joint venture between Plastic Packaging (Pty) Ltd and Ango Plasticos Lda will establish this factory about 10 km outside Lubango in the Humpata Municipal Area (ANIP Zone B) in the Huila Province in south Angola on an 18,000 m2 industrial plot owned by Ango Plasticos Lda. A new 1,000 m2 building will be constructed for the dual extrusion production lines. The maximum capacity of the new plastic packaging factory will be 1,500 tons per year (determined by the extruders).Presently, there is no local factory for the manufacturing of a variety of client-specific high quality packaging materials which is demanded by the Angolan market. The technology of dual extrusion production as intended to be used, is not yet introduced in Angola, and also not used by Plastic Packaging (Pty) Ltd.Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)The project partners will formulate a joint CRS policy for the new company e.g. including labour issues, environmental protection, quality management procedures (ISO 9001:2008).Impact•	Employment and working conditionsApart from local laws, all members of staff will receive free transport to and from work. Free meals will be provided during working hours. Personal health and hygiene training will be provided to all by a local health organisation contracted by the company. In case workers are ill, they will also have access to the medical services and care of this organisation.Members of staff, wishing to follow a training that will enhance their professional capacities, will be supported by the company. The costs of the course or training programme will be covered.•	Innovation / Transfer of knowledgeAlthough the bulk of the products might not be new for the country, since it is imported by the local partner, the production process is innovative, especially dual extrusion. In addition to that, the quality of the productions will be improved.•	Chain effectsThe local shareholder will no longer be dependent on supply by road from Namibia, and will not have to pay import duties. It will be able to purchase the joint venture's new materials that can be marketed.Raw materials will still be imported since they are not available in Angola, other supplies e.g. carton, transports services will be sourced locally.•	Impact on the sectorThe company might be an example for the local plastic sector: it will be the first one being ISO certified and the first one that recycles the waste produced during the process.•	EnvironmentPlastic in the environment is a negative aspect, however the project partners are aware of that and will recycle plastic as much as possible. They will also start up awareness campaigns and cleaning campaigns as they do in Namibia.•	Position of womenAbout 50% of the medium-/high-level staff will be female. The production process itself does not encourage woman to participate in the process so the number of basic-skilled women involved might be low.

The project will result in the establishment of a manufacturing plant of high quality plastic packaging. The factory will initially produce four types of products for Angola: carrier bags and other plastic bags, high quality shrink film, drums (printed),

title_narrative: Production of high quality plastic packaging for the Angolan market
description_narrative: Plastic Packaging (Pty) Ltd from Namibia is a producer and supplier of polyethylene products as carrier bags, refuse bags, heavy duty bags, shrink sheets etc. Customers of these products are from the meat and fishing industry, the wholesale and retail industry. During the years, they have established several daughter companies and joint ventures (e.g. in South Africa).During the late 1990s, Plastic Packaging (Pty) Ltd expanded its activities to Angola and its daughter in Angola, Ango Plasticos Lda was established, with headquarters in Lubango (Southern Angola). Apart from that, also four branch offices for sales and distribution were established in Angola. Presently, all products sold in Angola are imported from Namibia.In order toa) meet the growing market demand,b) reduce the costs (transport and import duties) andc) become less dependent of the South African rand,the management of Ango Plasticos Lda would like to establish an own production facility in Angola (Lubango) to serve the Angolan market directly. This market (retailers, manufacturers, agricultural and fish process industries) demand more and more diversified and tailor-made packaging products.The joint venture between Plastic Packaging (Pty) Ltd and Ango Plasticos Lda will establish this factory about 10 km outside Lubango in the Humpata Municipal Area (ANIP Zone B) in the Huila Province in south Angola on an 18,000 m2 industrial plot owned by Ango Plasticos Lda. A new 1,000 m2 building will be constructed for the dual extrusion production lines. The maximum capacity of the new plastic packaging factory will be 1,500 tons per year (determined by the extruders).Presently, there is no local factory for the manufacturing of a variety of client-specific high quality packaging materials which is demanded by the Angolan market. The technology of dual extrusion production as intended to be used, is not yet introduced in Angola, and also not used by Plastic Packaging (Pty) Ltd.Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)The project partners will formulate a joint CRS policy for the new company e.g. including labour issues, environmental protection, quality management procedures (ISO 9001:2008).Impact•	Employment and working conditionsApart from local laws, all members of staff will receive free transport to and from work. Free meals will be provided during working hours. Personal health and hygiene training will be provided to all by a local health organisation contracted by the company. In case workers are ill, they will also have access to the medical services and care of this organisation.Members of staff, wishing to follow a training that will enhance their professional capacities, will be supported by the company. The costs of the course or training programme will be covered.•	Innovation / Transfer of knowledgeAlthough the bulk of the products might not be new for the country, since it is imported by the local partner, the production process is innovative, especially dual extrusion. In addition to that, the quality of the productions will be improved.•	Chain effectsThe local shareholder will no longer be dependent on supply by road from Namibia, and will not have to pay import duties. It will be able to purchase the joint venture's new materials that can be marketed.Raw materials will still be imported since they are not available in Angola, other supplies e.g. carton, transports services will be sourced locally.•	Impact on the sectorThe company might be an example for the local plastic sector: it will be the first one being ISO certified and the first one that recycles the waste produced during the process.•	EnvironmentPlastic in the environment is a negative aspect, however the project partners are aware of that and will recycle plastic as much as possible. They will also start up awareness campaigns and cleaning campaigns as they do in Namibia.•	Position of womenAbout 50% of the medium-/high-level staff will be female. The production process itself does not encourage woman to participate in the process so the number of basic-skilled women involved might be low.

The project will result in the establishment of a manufacturing plant of high quality plastic packaging. The factory will initially produce four types of products for Angola: carrier bags and other plastic bags, high quality shrink film, drums (printed),

title_narrative: Livaningo
description_narrative: Livaningo means lighthouse.  It is a progressive and innovative NGO which is working for the sustainable management of environment, natural resources and for community’s social welfare and social justice. Livaningo’s strength is promoting campaigns against illegal exploration of land/forests and environmental pollution.  Livaningo´s strategic plan for 2016-2025 has four intervention areas; monitoring and transparency of government of natural resources, promote good urban governances, adaption to climate change and renewable energies, organizational development.

Livaningo develops activities in 4 of 11 provinces, they also monitor some processes and mega projects in one more province (Tete).

Monitoring and transparency of government of natural resources; Livaningo continues in the campaign Não to proSavana, this year Ministry of Agriculture showed new initiatives and invited civil society organizations to discuss the program. Livaningo contributed to the New National Mangrove Strategy and participated in discussions on the national standard definition of forest certification under FSC. Thanks to Livaningo´s activities some communities got the right to use a small part of revenues from the extractive industry for the benefit of the community, interaction between extractive industry companies and civil society has increased and government has an increased awareness in monitoring license processes.


On local level, thanks to Livaningo´s activities natural resource management committees strengthened their role and rights in relation to new concessions and compensations, in one province a dialogue platform between civil society and government was established which improve transparency around management of forest and faunistic resources. Communities have improved knowledge in advocacy and how to negotiate with investors’, strengthened their capacity for local social and economic development, natural resources management.

Promote good urban governance; Livaningo managed legal assistance for resettlement to 246 families affected when a waste landfill site collapsed. Local development committees are now independent and manage to find solutions on local problems without Livaningo´s support. Local committees work for families affected by the destruction of the land fill site. A zinc sheet and plastic factory has reduced the pollution thanks to work done by Livaningo and community. A march against open air waste landfills directed to the government and in solidarity with the victims from the above mentioned accident gathered 1600 persons.

Adaptation to climate changes and renewable energies; Livaningo focused on activities related to alternative energy sources for rural and semi-urban communities reducing their consumption of woody bio mass and consequently the pressure on forests. Among other activities, 2 workshops on clean energy resulted in actions from the government as an Integrated Energy Master Plan, National Strategy for Electrification and a Platform for solar energy.

The government reacted positively on civil society group, where Livaningo is active, which addressed not to accept import or export of GMO products. Since last year Livaningo opened 5 more sale site for environmentally friendly stoves totalizing more than 2 500 families now using these stoves and reducing the use of firewood.

title_narrative: Tradin Organic Agriculture: Valorising the mango value chain in The Gambia
description_narrative: 5 to 10 years ago, the government of fragile state The Gambia heavily promoted the cultivation of mangos which has led to the current abundance of mangos and price droppings. A lack of market access opportunities, combined with inefficiencies in the mango chain, has resulted in extremely high crop losses for farmers during the short (4 months) mango season, challenging their livelihoods.Tradin is currently one of the world’s biggest suppliers of organic dried mango which are imported from West Africa (amongst others). In order to meet world-wide growing demand for dried mangos, the company aimed to develop an organic dried mango value chain and increase production in The Gambia by investing in its young local partner Tropingo Foods. Technical Assistance (DGGF) is used to invest in the set-up of an organic supply chain, additional equipment and drying facilities, improvement of quality- and operational processes within the facility and a feasibility study for a large scale factory and mango plantation. The project is the first to process mango and the first ‘organic’ project in the country. It supported 200+ direct jobs (80 FTE) and 256 indirect jobs of smallholder farmers in the supply chain. Both, the employees in the processing facility as the mango farmers, received training on good manufacturing practices and good agricultural practices, including organic production and these farmers are now cultivating according to international organic standards leading to new income streams. As a result of the Technical Assistance, the factory is now an approved vendor and certified supplier of dried mangos. Further investments are currently being explored and may result in the creation of more than 500 new jobs in the next few years.

title_narrative: NGO Forum III, South Sudan
NGO Forum III, Sydsudan
description_narrative: Support to NGO Forum - a coordination forum for NGOs in South Sudan.  The goal of the NGO Forum is to help improve conditions to carry out  development and humanitarian work in South Sudan. To achieve this the NGO Forum supports the coordination, communication, advocacy,         capacity development, and security cooperation between organisations  in South Sudan.

NGO Forums mål är att bidra till att förbättra förutsättningarna för att de stora utvecklingsmässiga och humanitära behoven i Södra Sudan ska kunna mötas. För att uppnå detta stödjer NGO Forum samordning, kommunikation, påverkansarbete, kapacitetsutveckling, samt säkerhetssamarbete bland det stora antal NGOs som levererar social service och bidrar till fred och säkerhet i landet. NGO Forum representerar även alla icke-statliga organisationer, både lokala och internationella, i södra Sudan. Det är Sidas bedömning att NGO Forums verksamhet, som utformats av medlemmarna under många års samarbete, är relevant, effektiv och motsvarar behoven i en föränderlig och synnerligen utmanande kontext. Det är Sidas bedömning att NGO Forums sekretariat har erfoderlig kapacitet att fortsätta genomföra dess aktiviteter, samt att Tearfund (som administratör för sekreteriatet) utgör en tillförlitlig samarbetspartner.

title_narrative: NGO Consortium
description_narrative: Somalia remains in a state of a complex humanitarian emergency characterised by multifaceted factors including volatile political environment, extreme poverty, food insecurity, conflict and instability. Over 3.1 million people are in humanitarian emergency and crisis, 6.2 million people in need of assistance and 1.1 million people in protracted internal displacement. The operating environment in Somalia remains volatile and challenging and access to those in need continues to be impeded by a range of factors culminating to the already stressful working environment and debilitating humanitarian partners from providing timely assistance to vulnerable populations. Humanitarian organisations have continued to report significant increases in bureaucratic impediments particularly in Puntland and southern Somalia. The Consortium continues to advocate for favourable working environment for NGOs to deliver aid to those in need through its core activities of coordination, representation, advocacy and information sharing. Development of press releases/position papers further expresses NGOs voices and concerns and acts as advocacy tools to raise awareness, in particular media awareness, on the plight of Somalis with a focus on thematic issues. It is believed that these communiques influence decisions. Moreover, frequent visits to Mogadishu and in key Regional State capitals (Garowe, Baidoa and Kismayo) are paramount to advocate for amicable solutions to arising administrative impediments. In June 2014, the NGO Consortium commissioned a study on Risk Management amp Accountability (RMA) practices among NGOs in Somalia to map out and analyse NGO standards and approaches in risk management and mitigation in Somalia and Somaliland. NGO Consortium members identified common approaches to mitigating risks, capacity building on risk management and developed guidelines on common risk management standards. NGOs agreed to openly and honestly appraise their risk management methods that they practiced as well as share information with other NGOs to enhance transparency and encourage information sharing among NGOs. Members then endorsed these “Guidelines (Code of Conduct) for RMA practices for NGOs operating in Somalia/Somaliland”. The Consortium anticipates hiring a consultant to conduct an evidence-based assessment of NGO compliance and implementation of the risk management guidelines with a view to identifying the effectiveness of risk management systems to continue to build momentum towards strengthening risk management approaches. Moreover, the aim of this assessment is to check the relevance and possibly revise the guidelines to suit the current Somalia situation. As the key coordination mechanism for local and international NGOs working in Somalia on a wide range of issues and sectors, the Consortium continues to reiterate the crucial role played by NGOs to address need while adapting to the changing context in Somalia, advocating for the interests of Somalis both inside and outside Somalia, looking beyond emergency response to promote aid effectiveness while supporting the development of Somali NGOs’ capacity and increasing their accountability to communities and donors. The Consortium anticipates facilitating a durable solutions roundtable discussion with key players with the aim to generate dialogue on plausible solutions to the large scale and protracted refugee situations in Somalia as well as capacity building for NGOs on Access Negotiation and a course on Introduction to Working in Somalia. Though the humanitarian development nexus discourse may be at its infant stage, it is essential to strengthen linkages between humanitarian and development activities in order to create and maintain lasting solutions to Somalia’s dependence on humanitarian aid, a notion desired by the current government.

title_narrative: NGO Support / Citizen Welfare Support and Resource Centre
description_narrative:
Tanzania is at a crucial stage of development: high economic growth large findings of natural resources with high potential for revenues key political processes including new constitution (2014) and multi-party elections (2015) high population growth and i
ncreasing inequality. Wealth for some but wide-spread poverty for the vast majority combined with special challenges of the most vulnerable groups of society and major environmental problems (deforestation impact of climate change pollution due to extracti
on of natural resources) are some of the major challenges over the next decade. In this process of change civil society organisations have an important role to play firstly as advocates of the most vulnerable people and on changes needed in terms of policy
 and implementation and secondly as service providers for vulnerable groups who are without care. However the capacity of NGOs remains low especially in terms of ability to perform advocacy work. There is a need to further increase the capacity and profess
ionalism of NGOs and to strengthen their coordination and cooperation.Key aim of the CISUNET project is to achieve socially and ecologically sustainable development and reduction of poverty. While the first phase (2008-2010) and second  phase (2011-2013) p
rioritized on strengthening the working capacity and networking of local NGOs the third phase (2014-2016) will precedence strengthening the advocacy element of NGO work. It will increase the capability of Tanzanian civil society via community-based NGOs an
d umbrella NGO TACOSODE to influence policy and decision-making towards reduction of poverty and inequality and to perform advocacy work to improve the situation and rights of the most vulnerable groups (women children people with disabilities people livin
g with HIV/AIDS elderly people unemployed youths etc.). Further the project increases the capacity and networking of Tanzanian NGOs among NGOs themselves and between NGOs and the public and private sectors on a local national and international level. It pr
omotes understanding on issues of globalisation and development among social and health NGOs in Finland and internationally via the global umbrella organisation ICSW thus promoting North-South cooperation. Means of intervention are assessment of local NGOs
, training workshops and seminars, regional national and international awareness-raising, provision of IT equipment and internet access to NGO networks.

title_narrative: South Sudan NGO Forum 2015-2016
Sydsudan NGO Forum 2015-2016
description_narrative: One-year support to South Sudan NGO Forum Secretariat 2015-2016. NGO  Forum is a platform with members from national and international      civil society organisations in South Sudan. NGO Forum aims at         strenghtened coordination, exchange and partly capacity development   for CS actors with humanitarian and development operations in SSD.    The support is a continuation of prev Swedish support since 2012.

Tearfund har ansökt Sidamedel om 4,9 MSEK för att fortsätta bedriva NGO Forum Secretariat i Sydsudan 2015-2016. Sekretariatets övergripande mål är att skapa bättre förutsättningar för civilsamhällsorganisationer att möta de utvecklingsmässiga och humanitära behoven som präglar landet. NGO Forum spelar en viktig roll som koordinator och påverkansaktör för både nationella och internationella icke-statliga organisationer (NGO:er) verksamma i Sydsudan. För närvarande består forumet av ca 145 internationella och 200 nationella medlemsorganisationer. Forumet styrs av årligt utvalda styrkommittéer och koordineras bland annat genom olika tematiska arbetsgrupper; påverkan, säkerhet, personal/HR och kapacitetsutveckling. Genom samordning och informationsspridning är syftet att skapa ett bättre klimat för NGO:er att verka i landet. 

Det är Sidas bedömning att NGO Forums verksamhet, som utformats av forumets medlemmar under många års samarbete, är relevant, effektivt och motsvarar behoven i en föränderlig och synnerligen utmanande kontext. Det är Sidas bedömning att NGO Forums sekretariat har erforderlig kapacitet att fortsätta genomföra dess aktiviteter, samt att Tearfund (som administratör för sekretariatet) utgör en tillförlitlig samarbetspartner. Bedömningen görs utifrån Sidas tidigare erfarenheter av stöd till NGO Forum med Tearfund som samarbetspartner. 

Insatsens totala budget är ca 10 MSEK, varav 49 % är stöd från Sida och 38 % från andra givare (ECHO & SDC). NGO Forum Sekretariatet står själva för 13 % som beräknas komma in genom bland annat medlemsavgifter. 

Sidas förra stöd till Tearfund avslutades i augusti 2015 och Tearfund har i sin begäran ansökt om nya medel för perioden 1 september 2015 till 31 augusti 2016. Ansökan ankom emellertid Sida först i september och slutlig rapportering för tidigare fas färdigställdes under oktober och november. Ett större glapp i den svenska, enda helt icke-öronmärkta finanseringen till NGO Forums sekretariat, skulle dock påverka verksamheten negativt. Det föreslås därför att Sida godkänner delvis retroaktivt stöd till insatsen för perioden 1 oktober 2015 till 30 september 2016.

title_narrative: Food Security Program with Hope for Angola - 2014
description_narrative:
Stop Hunger Now works to support the development efforts of Hope for Angola by providing meals for crisis relief and medical programs in Angola.

Hope For Angola is a 501(c)(3) non governmental organization founded by Angolans living in the United States to respond to social and economic problems faced by the people of Angola, especially those in the most vulnerable groups. This shipment will support the Angolan people who are suffering from a two year-long drought. According to the United Nations, 1.8 million Angolans have been affected by the drought in ten of the fourteen provinces and among them, a third of the affected are children. For this particular shipment, the focus is to assist 25,000 drought affected people in the province of Cunene, namely the localities of Cahama, Otchinjau, Xangongo and Ondjiva. The meals will also support a medical clinic in Odjiva.
local community, those affected by severe drought

description_narrative: Volunteer in cooperation with the staff of Caritas Czech Republic will engage in the following activities: - Cooperation in the preparation of training modules for the Mongolian Social Workers - Helping to research human rights in prisons in Mongolia - Building their own capacity for future projects in Mongolia - Developing cooperation Statues - Identification of possible involvement of Slovak entities in projects in the field of good governance in Mongolia - Capacity Building in monitoring of human rights education and human rights in prisons, - Development education activities

title_narrative: Ingobyi Activity
description_narrative: (Rwanda):  USAID's Ingobyi activity (Ingobyi refers to a cushion to carry infants or sick people), provides technical assistance at all levels of Rwanda's health system to improve the capacity of health professionals to prevent maternal and child deaths. The activity is focused in 20 of Rwanda's 30 districts. Ingobyi will train, mentor and supervise doctors, nurses and midwives to improve clinical competencies in antenatal care; emergency obstetric and newborn care; management of childhood illnesses; family planning; infection control and prevention; and management of sexual and gender-based violence at the facility level.  At the community level, Ingobyi will train and supervise community health workers to correctly diagnose and treat malaria, pneumonia, diarrhea and provide reproductive health services.  Ingobyi will improve the quality of data captured in the Health Management Information System and its use in decision making. Ingobyi will also support social and behavior change interventions to improve adoption of healthy reproductive maternal, child and adolescent health behaviors, including hygiene, sanitation, nutrition, and malaria. .Rwanda's pre-service medical system is weak and lacks experienced professionals to provide ongoing clinical mentorship. Ingobyi therefore partners with the Government of Rwanda and local medical professional associations that will continue to provide ongoing in-service training to raise the overall clinical competencies of providers, in order to build a more professional cadre of medical providers. .Ingobyi's focus on improving healthcare directly contributes to the Mission's Development Objective 1 of improved health outcomes and overall goal of strengthening human capital.  .. .. ... .

title_narrative: Developing Mongolian Medical infrastructure through enhanced training of Doctors for evaluation for and in-flight patient care.
description_narrative:
The overall objective is to improve the access to medical care and treatment for all Mongolians regardless of where they live. Specialized health care of one million people in Mongolian vast countryside depends on the medical services available in the capi
tal but undeveloped road network hinders patient transfers by road. Consequently Mongolia is developing in-flight medical transfers to help countryside hospitals with only basic treatment capability. This project develops the capacity of the Mongolian Emer
gency Medical network of the Ministry of Health. The health care professionals working in this area have received limited or no training in the field of patient transport or in-flight patient care. Training by Finnish aeromedical experts enables Mongolian 
doctors to make transport safe for patients requiring treatment in the capital. This increases the quality and capacity Mongolian medical and health infrastructure.Mongolian doctors lack current training in relevant aeromedical issues and in-flight patient
 care. The patient security is compromised when medical flights are requested to remote areas in Mongolia where doctors and nurses have no aeromedical knowledge. There is lack of understanding on general principles of patient transfers and phenomena caused
 by reduced pressure and oxygen levels in-flight. Receiving specific training on patient transfers and in-flight patient care by Finnish aeromedical experts will enhance Mongolian Medical infrastructure and result in safer and more secure medical flights. 
This training is also applicable to any transport of patients. Thereby it will build the infrastructure and capacity of the health care system and emergency patient care system in Mongolia.
